docs.lead_paragraph: A 24-year-old pregnant woman was attacked in her apartment by her companion Saturday, the police said, and had stillborn twins yesterday. Investigators said the companion, Anthony Puglia, was arrested yesterday and charged with assault. They said the woman, whose identity was not disclosed, was attacked at 11:45 p.m. Saturday in the apartment she shared with Mr. Puglia at 3192 Webster Avenue in Norwood. She delivered the twins at North Central Bronx Hospital. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Pregnant Woman Assaulted

docs.abstract: Anthony Puglia is charged with attacking his unidentified pregnant companion in her apartment in Norwood section of Bronx, who then delivers stillborn twins (S)

byline.original: By Thomas J. Lueck (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: Alfredo Castellano stabbed his hook through a hunk of raw fish and cast bait and sinker toward Queens. Then he sat next to his wife, Carmen, their backs to the thigh-high retaining wall separating them from dense traffic on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. The sun had just dipped behind the housing projects of East Harlem, offering slight relief from the evening swelter. Their 7-year-old son, Giovanni, jumped and giggled, dodging his friend Jasmine, 11, as she swung in a hammock strung between a plane tree and a lamppost.

headline.main: Reeling In Many a Meal on the East River, and Maybe a Risky Mess of PCB's

docs.abstract: Men and women fishing waters around New York City often disregard warnings about PCB contamination; most of those fishing are poor, especially in East River near Harlem, believing fish come from somewhere safe from pollution; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''WHEN I look around today, the biggest anachronism I see is pregnancy,'' Andy Warhol wrote in ''The Philosophy of Andy Warhol (From A to B and Back Again).'' ''I just can't believe that people are still pregnant.'' That was in 1975. In 2003, Jessica Craig-Martin finds the fact even more appalling. Ms. Craig-Martin, the art-cum-fashion photographer whose often unflattering, paparazzi-style photos of night-life warriors bring to mind a strange mix of Warhol, Weegee and Dian Fossey, has become painfully familiar with the realities of incipient single motherhood, with three weeks more to go as host to what feels like a gorilla in her midst.
docs.abstract: Possessed column on fashion photographer Jessica Craig-Martin, whose prized possession is a Polaroid SX-70 camera; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LOOKING for love in all the wrong places, Sharon Gray, a 30-something political lobbyist, is hounded by the tick-tock of her biological clock. She barrels through life using her feminine wiles and political savvy to compromise the hearts and pocketbooks of less-than-savory Big Apple operatives. A valuable cable franchise is about to be awarded, and Sharon works the telephones to insure her multi-million dollar cut from those who stand to gain most -- a developer, a city councilman and a Puerto Rican community leader.

headline.main: What to Do About That Pain in the Neck

docs.lead_paragraph: The 226th annual session of the New York State Legislature ended on June 20, a day later than it was scheduled to, after a flurry of last-minute negotiations that stretched into the early hours but failed to resolve disputes over several major bills. The tempestuous finish of the regularly scheduled session capped an unusual year in which the Senate's Republican majority and the Assembly's Democratic majority banded together in May and passed a $92.8 billion budget over Gov. George E. Pataki's vetoes.

headline.main: A Summary of the Major Actions of the Legislature's 226th Session

docs.abstract: Summary of 226th session of New York State Legislature, which was notable in that Senate's Republican majority and Assembly's Democratic majority banded together to pass $92.8 billion budget over vetoes by Gov George E Pataki; perhaps most important bill passed by Legislature was statewide ban on smoking in workplace; photos (L)

byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and AL BAKER

docs.lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn woman who was nine months pregnant was found shot dead early yesterday inside her home in Flatlands, the police said. She had been shot once in the head, and was taken to Kings County Hospital. Her baby did not survive.
docs.abstract: Lamethia McCollum, 28-year-old pregnant woman, is found shot dead at her home in Flatlands, Brooklyn (S)
docs.snippet: A Brooklyn woman who was nine months pregnant was found shot dead early yesterday inside her home in Flatlands, the police said.     She had been shot once in the head, and was taken to Kings County Hospital. Her baby did not survive.
